citations.narrative:
Two primary enclosures do not have a sufficient public barrier present. One primary enclosure houses 1 dromedary
camel, 1 capybara, 3 red kangaroo, and 3 rabbits and the other contains 6 goats, 2 zebu, 1 sheep and 4 pigs. During
inspection many people were observed by the inspector on the inside of an incomplete wire barrier. Failure to provide
public barriers increases the risk of harm to both the animals and the public. The licensee must ensure that animals are
handled so there is minimal risk of harm to the animals and the public. Additionally, there must be sufficient distance
and/or barriers between the animals and the general viewing public as to assure the safety of the animals and the public.
Correct by July 1, 2023.

There is not an identifiable, readily available attendant during all areas and times of public contact with animals. The pens
flanking the entry pathway allow for direct contact with the public to take place through a fence. One pen contains 6
goats, 2 zebu, 1 sheep, and 4 pigs. The second pen contains 1 dromedary camel, 1 capybara, 3 red kangaroo, and 3
rabbits. At the time of inspection, no dedicated attendant was present to monitor the public contact.
Without an attendant, animals are at greater risk of experiencing physical injury and behavioral stress, and members of
the public may be at greater risk of injury. Correct by ensuring that a responsible, knowledgeable, and readily identifiable
attendants are always present during periods of public contact.
Correct by June 1, 2023

There is an enclosure that houses 2 female domestic rabbits, 1 rehabilitated female cotton-tail rabbit, 1 pheasant, and
many quail. In another enclosure there are 3 male domestic rabbits, 1 capybara, 1 dromedary camel, 3 red kangaroos,
emu, ostrich, and multiple guinea fowl. Housing rabbits with other species may result in injury to the rabbits. Rabbits must
not be housed in the same primary enclosure with any other species for their health and safety. Correct by housing
rabbits without other species present.
Correct by June 1, 2023

In the pen containing 6 goats, 2 zebu, 1 sheep, and 4 pigs there is a damaged shade structure and the bottom of the
enclosure fence had been lifted and bent in numerous places leaving gaps between the fence and the ground. The metal
sides of the shade structure have been forcibly ripped off screws and bent up leaving exposed corners of sheet metal.
Enclosures must be constructed and maintained so that they protect the animals from injury and contain the animals.
Correct by repairing or replacing these items to ensure that the enclosures protect the animals from injury and escape.
Correct by June 18, 2023

There is insufficient shelter from inclement weather for the 1 dromedary camel, 7 goats, 2 zebu, 1 sheep, 4 pigs, 2 Asiatic
water buffalo, 3 American bison, and 4 cattle. Natural or artificial shelter appropriate to the local climatic conditions for the
species concerned shall be provided for all animals kept outdoors to afford them protection and to prevent discomfort to
such animals. Correct by ensuring that there is appropriate shelter for all animals in the enclosures.
Correct by July 1, 2023

An automatic waterer for the pigs was leaking onto the ground and a roughly 5-foot diameter pool of standing water
surrounded both automatic waterers in the enclosure. To utilize either waterer an animal would be required to walk
through this pool of water. Standing water can cause unsound footing or potential for illness if to the hooves, skin or GI
tract. A suitable method shall be provided to rapidly eliminate excess water.
Correct by June 18, 2023

The enclosure which houses 1 dromedary camel, 1 capybara, 3 red kangaroo, and 3 rabbits does not have an adequate
perimeter fence. A perimeter fence protects animals from contact with unauthorized people and animals. A perimeter
fence also acts as a secondary containment system if an animal escapes from its primary enclosure. Correct by installing
a perimeter fence that is at least 6 feet tall and at least 3 feet from the enclosure to keep animals and unauthorized
persons out, and to act as a secondary containment system for animals in the facility. Alternatively, a variance may be
requested in writing from the APHIS Administrator.
Correct by July 1, 2023.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with a facility representative.
n

narrative:
2.131(c)(1) 
   
Handling of animals. 
Two primary enclosures do not have a sufficient public barrier present.  One primary enclosure houses 1 dromedary 
camel, 1 capybara, 3 red kangaroo, and 3 rabbits and the other contains 6 goats, 2 zebu, 1 sheep and 4 pigs. During 
inspection many people were observed by the inspector on the inside of an incomplete wire barrier.  Failure to provide 
public barriers increases the risk of harm to both the animals and the public. The licensee must ensure that animals are 
handled so there is minimal risk of harm to the animals and the public. Additionally, there must be sufficient distance 
and/or barriers between the animals and the general viewing public as to assure the safety of the animals and the public.  
Correct by July 1, 2023. 
2.131(d)(2) 
   
Handling of animals. 
There is not an identifiable, readily available attendant during all areas and times of public contact with animals. The pens 
flanking the entry pathway allow for direct contact with the public to take place through a fence.  One pen contains 6 
goats, 2 zebu, 1 sheep, and 4 pigs.  The second pen contains 1 dromedary camel, 1 capybara, 3 red kangaroo, and 3 
rabbits. At the time of inspection, no dedicated attendant was present to monitor the public contact.  
Without an attendant, animals are at greater risk of experiencing physical injury and behavioral stress, and members of

the public may be at greater risk of injury. Correct by ensuring that a responsible, knowledgeable, and readily identifiable 
attendants are always present during periods of public contact. 
Correct by June 1, 2023 
3.58(a) 
   
Classification and separation. 
There is an enclosure that houses 2 female domestic rabbits, 1 rehabilitated female cotton-tail rabbit, 1 pheasant, and 
many quail. In another enclosure there are 3 male domestic rabbits, 1 capybara, 1 dromedary camel, 3 red kangaroos, 
emu, ostrich, and multiple guinea fowl.  Housing rabbits with other species may result in injury to the rabbits. Rabbits must 
not be housed in the same primary enclosure with any other species for their health and safety. Correct by housing 
rabbits without other species present.   
Correct by June 1, 2023 
3.125(a) 
   
Facilities, general. 
In the pen containing 6 goats, 2 zebu, 1 sheep, and 4 pigs there is a damaged shade structure and the bottom of the 
enclosure fence had been lifted and bent in numerous places leaving gaps between the fence and the ground.  The metal 
sides of the shade structure have been forcibly ripped off screws and bent up leaving exposed corners of sheet metal.  
Enclosures must be constructed and maintained so that they protect the animals from injury and contain the animals. 
Correct by repairing or replacing these items to ensure that the enclosures protect the animals from injury and escape. 
Correct by June 18, 2023 
3.127(b) 
   
Facilities, outdoor.

There is insufficient shelter from inclement weather for the 1 dromedary camel, 7 goats, 2 zebu, 1 sheep, 4 pigs, 2 Asiatic 
water buffalo, 3 American bison, and 4 cattle.  Natural or artificial shelter appropriate to the local climatic conditions for the 
species concerned shall be provided for all animals kept outdoors to afford them protection and to prevent discomfort to 
such animals. Correct by ensuring that there is appropriate shelter for all animals in the enclosures. 
Correct by July 1, 2023 
3.127(c) 
   
Facilities, outdoor. 
An automatic waterer for the pigs was leaking onto the ground and a roughly 5-foot diameter pool of standing water 
surrounded both automatic waterers in the enclosure.  To utilize either waterer an animal would be required to walk 
through this pool of water.  Standing water can cause unsound footing or potential for illness if to the hooves, skin or GI 
tract.  A suitable method shall be provided to rapidly eliminate excess water. 
Correct by June 18, 2023 
3.127(d) 
   
Facilities, outdoor. 
The enclosure which houses 1 dromedary camel, 1 capybara, 3 red kangaroo, and 3 rabbits does not have an adequate 
perimeter fence. A perimeter fence protects animals from contact with unauthorized people and animals. A perimeter 
fence also acts as a secondary containment system if an animal escapes from its primary enclosure. Correct by installing 
a perimeter fence that is at least 6 feet tall and at least 3 feet from the enclosure to keep animals and unauthorized 
persons out, and to act as a secondary containment system for animals in the facility. Alternatively, a variance may be 
requested in writing from the APHIS Administrator.  
Correct by July 1, 2023.

This inspection and exit interview were conducted with a facility representative.

species.common: DOMESTIC PIG / POTBELLY PIG / MICRO PIG
